												Into the Dark is a FPS horror game. The player takes control of Peter O’ Brannon, a detective who is sent to investigate the death of an elderly man in New England. Upon arriving at his cabin, you realise that all is not right and something sinister is going on.The game makes a poor first impression. The game starts with ultra-low quality artwork and a surprisingly small amount of menu options, there is absolutely no configuration options. To configure the controls you have to edit a text file.Gameplay consists of exploring bland locations, completing bland objectives and killing bland enemies. In order to complete the games puzzles, you often have to go back to rooms you have already explored to find that objects have magically spawned there. When you finally get past the obstacle, the game is kind enough to spawn an enemy directly behind you.The graphics are bad. Into the Dark features completely antiquated visuals.The voice acting for the game is beyond awful. For me it was nearly impossible to hear what is being said, it made it nearly impossible to follow the story.If that is not enough, there are several technical issues; invisible walls block a door or you could stuck in such a wall. Loading up a saved game, starting a new level and even just doing nothing: all of them can cause crashes.The best part in Into the Dark is that it includes the complete movie of Night of the Living Dead.My advice take a look at other horror games. Posted: August 12, 2014
												Usually I dont play more than 2 or 3 games per year, no time for more......so perhaps I should have been more picky before throwing myself into the dark here.Or better not.It is hard to tell what the game actually is. I could write a book about it and still it wouldnt cover all aspects.Is it the next "oh look how bad it is" experience like surgeon or goat simulator?Nope.Is it a trash game as advertised?Yes, it has a certain B-movie atmosphere, it is extremely cheesy when it wants to be, but its not something that feels put together cheap and quickly. The sheer amount of small details hidden in all parts of the levels tells otherwise.As well as the fact that political events from the last three years are covered and the game had been in development since 2011.Is it a horror game?It has jump scares and goosebump moments, but thats not the essenceIs it a shooter?You have some challenging firefights, but thats also not the essence of the game.Is it an adventure?Nope, while there are some interesting puzzles, most of the tasks are looking for keys and items that are used by pressing "Enter" on a single spot.Is it funny?Oh my god, yes, it is!Is it worth the time and money?For me a clear "yes" on that one.Is it a good game?Well, thats the point where things get complicated.If you are one of those players who expect a game to explain everything to you, to lead and guide you, to highlight and show all you need to do, a game that pats you on your shoulder for klicking the button it has highlighted previously, run away and never look back. You have no right to be here.If you dont have a PC that is at least between the min and the recommended specs, forget this game. When I play on my office machine, which is close to the min specs, I get all the bad behaviour people are complaining about - > sloppy physics, stuck monster, horrible AI, sloppy responsiveness. When I switch to my gaming laptop, I get superlethal soldiers chasing me around using elevators and hideouts, beutiful ragdolling, smooth gameplay...If you dont agree to the developers arrogant demand to play the game as righthander with WASD controls, think twice. There is no option menu. And when I tell you no options menu, I am dead serious. All is changed in a script (including screen brightness, which is another, different script), and there are multiple-pages tutorials on how to do so. The devs are supportive, they will even write you custom ini scripts, but the sheer blatant arrogance to publish a game without options menu is so amazing that I am not even mad.If you stop playing a game because of occasional crashes, turn around here. They are rare, some can be prevented, there is always a savegame to load afterwards - but you wont get through without experiencing them.If you are a success-driven finisher, a player who is dedicated to "beat" a game as fast and efficient as possible, spend your money on something else.Read the following lines:"Mc Carthy""Necronomicon""Maniac Mansion""Nikola Tesla""Giana Sisters""Commodore 64""George Romero""Project Paperclip"If 4 or more didnt ring a bell, you are wrong here.However, if you made it so far without being sorted out, and if you are not cursed by either an IQ below the average room temperature or the unspeakable someone could call "typical German humor", you might enjoy this game to an unhealthy degree. Because it is unique, it is funny, it is intriguing - if played right. And that means taking your time, reading the ingame notes, the mission notes (triggered by "M"), tinkering around to follow the hints, reading most of the paper pieces hidden on walls, floors, drawers, listening to the dialogues (oh my god, that voice acting alone will either brake you or make you laugh) and, most of all, trying out even the most stupid things. Like getting drunk before a fight or playing a piano in a brothel full of zombie hookers.The reward is a mixture of excellent jokes, insane easter eggs, funny references, a trashy B-Movie-storyline, shameless backtracking, dozens of "WTF" moments, some boobs and ♥♥♥♥♥s, even more trashy cutscenes and. if you get them, some really intelligent, subversive and cynical political statements.Plus "The Night of the Living Dead" to be seen in an ingame cinema, full lenghts, accompanied by some skeletons who claim to be extras from the movie.I still cant tell if its good for you, because so much depends on who you are. My personal opinion is that this game, in all its trashy quirkyness, is among my all-time-favorites and gave me plenty if really entertaining hours, hopefully there are more to come. The developers should be slapped for their lazyness, arrogance and disrespect for comfort functions, but afterwards I would praise them for something that is in its better moments far more entertaining than any AAA game today.Also, I am not stating "All people who dont find this game to be funny are stupid" as some other "fans" do, I go with "People who dont find this game to be funny are people I wouldnt invite to my parties".I love this game, but I cant tell if you will, too. At 10$ asked, you should try it yourself.PS: An interesting side note on the reviews. While they are mixed, there is a significant difference in the positive and negative reviews: Most positive reviews talk about the flaws, too, they warn, they tell "the recommendation depends on (insert variable)". Most negative reviews tell outright "its bad" or even (gosh!) "Its not funny" in a way that seems like the writer wants to tell others what to think. Some even bash those who like the game.So, while they certainly failed to create a perfect game, the devs perhaps suceeded in creating a playable hater detector :D

The graphics are bad in comparison to most other games (even most games in the price range), and the gameplay is nothing special besides a few semi-interesting puzzles. I recommend this only for those looking to see the technical limits of the FPSC engine in the "graphical" sense.@the developer: You can be proud of squeezing so much out of such an underpowered rag, and creating a believable, well thought out tale, but when it comes to the artistic side of things (aesthetics of scenery, custom non-model pack media), or the actual "funness" of the game (number of moments where I'm smiling, unconcerned that I am playing a video game), it's nowhere near worth the price tag. Had this game been free, it would have been compared to all the other free games i've played, and I would've loved it, but being a 7$ game, It gets compared to other AWESOME games that I've payed 7$ for like chaser or E.Y.E. or Hover: Revolt of Gamers, thus shining a bad light on this game.tl;dr: ok game, technically amazing for the game engine you used, but I would have preferred it to be free, even if it meant it was 1/4 the length. you could've definitely squeezed just as much humour and told the same story.

												I can appreciate the class of games out there that are soooo bad they are good. A great example of this is Rat Hunter (FPS) or Harvester (old point and click with FMV). I heard a lot of people say Into the Dark was a buggy pile of poop but was over the top, outrageous, and entertaining. I can put up with poorly made buggy games, but this game is in the class of:So Bad, that is really is Bad.The game is terribly frustraiting, with a lot of senseless, extremely poorly executed puzzles that are game stopping.Often, you will find yourself referencing a walkthru or reloading because you die so easily in the same room for any random reason. In FPS games, IT HAPPENS, but the load times are long for an old looking game like this (looks 15 years old). Nothing is explained well, you pretty much run around a series of rooms trying to figure out how to advance to the next room/rooms. This makes progression extremely slow and cumbersome. There are a lot of other features, situations, humor, etc., but you can never appreciate or enjoy them because you are too busy trapped in some place because there is no clear way to get out. I don't expect hand holding but the game is very vague and the mechanics are so poor they do not marry to what you need to do to progress. A lot of times, any in-game speech or text alludes to what you must do, but the game level doesn't match up with what they are talking about. "Put the bomb in the hole under the door". There are lots of doors and none have a hole - for example. The mechanics are extremely inconsistent with the game engine so prepare to screw up a lot.In fact, the puzzles are so bad, there are pictures of the game developer in the game giving you hints.In the level I mentioned, the other problem was just learning that you have to make a bomb. In a prior level, you could shoot an explosive "cube" from a distance to blast through. In another level, you find a cube, but it doesn't explode if you shoot it. So the rules change for that level without the player being told. You see some explosive gas tanks but they kill you regardless of distance. Once you get the bomb making materials, you have to put in on a lab table, but you are not told that, or which one. You just have to use the walkthru.  If this was some game where you are told there is a way to craft things, and these are the hotkeys, then that would make sense. But this is designed to operate as a simple FPS, so YEAH, the puzzle solutions totally do not marry well.The generic monster enemies charge you and pound you to death.There is no way to sneak around them and if you blow your ammo, you are screwed.That's fine, but sometimes, you can die in 5 hits or 1 hit. It's pretty random.Same with the enemies, one monster took 3 hits to die, another took 8.Headshots, heartshots, stuff like that don't even matter. So it's all random.This means, even if you conserve ammo, you can still use up your ammo, and still not bring the enemy down.They can also randomly spawn.If you want a very challenging PUZZLE game, give it a try, and don't use the walkthrus (even with, still challenging). If you want a run and gun FPS, pass. It's not that kind of game.It's too bad, if the game didn't have so many puzzles slowing it down, it would be much more enjoyable as a horror FPS. What's GOOD though: the dark grittiness, the cheapo-creepy atmosphere; I even enjoyed the bad voice acting.I surmise the obstacles were designed to MAKE THE GAME FEEL LONGER.After playing the "Into the Woods" free "game" that came with it,  the flaws of Into the Dark start to make sense. Into the Woods: you wake up in a forest and aren't told anything. No problem with that. You explore some ruins, find some ammo, a key, then bad guys spawn to kill you. Each small area is gated so you must find the key to get to the next one. It can be anywhere, laying in the grass, in one of many ruins, etc.When you finally get to a certain area, the game ends. EXTREMELY short.Now, imagine that indoors in cramped rooms, hallways, and puzzles mismatching with the FPS mechanics to SLOW PROGRESSION DOWN, instead of the outdoor distances you have to run to find a key laying in the grass somewhere.Add to it: they're very small glitchy levels with puzzles you often don't even know exist.Previously, this game was put out as a horror FPS. I noticed they now say it's an Adventure/FPS. LOL.Also, look at the description 11 levels but 67 puzzles. That's a lot of puzzles for such a small game with small "levels" (again, more like a collection of connected rooms).Thumbs down primarily due to:-Long Load Times-Puzzles that you didn't know were puzzles and that couldn't even be solved the way they need to, the way described, in a limited FPS game environment-Never got to see the much touted boobies and hookers!

												I see that there are a lot of people claiming that this game is the perfect B-Movie-Experience. Unfortunately neither these gamers nor the developer unterstand how the whole "So bad it's good"-thing works. Watching a bad and unintentionally humourus movie is like seeing someone fail and that is genuinely funny. It's like watching a skateboarder trying to do a trick but falling on his face over and over again. You just  know it is not the morally right thing to do but you still find it funny. Playing a bad game is more like being the skateboarder. While a game is still a guided experience someone else pulled out of his ***, you are in control and have to adapt to the scenarios the developer is throwing at you. That is why seeing a "Let's play" of a game like "Ride to Hell Retribution" is fun to watch the whole way through while actually playing it quickle dwindles to pure frustration."Into the dark" has no redeeming feature whatsowver. Even the humour is never as smart or self-aware as it wants to be. Refering to quantum physics and popcultur isn't funny without a context, it's just trying way to hard. However the game doesn't stop there: The controls are slow and clunky, the key bindings very uncomfortable, the graphics subpar and WAY to dark and the shooting mechanics unimpressive and overly frustrating with enemies often spawning behind you and clipping through virtually every object. The puzzle design shall not be named as such, with unintuitive solutions and keys randomly appearing. And if you still want to play it, get ready for the same one-minute piece of music repeated over and over again, even during menus."Into the Dark" is a bad joke that will be gone soon and rightfully so. If you want a B-movie experience I recommend "House of the Dead: Overkill". Comes without headaches.

												This game is an odd little fellow: On the one hand, "Ultimate Trash" quite hits the mark, and expecting deep and extensive game mechanics is beyond its point. But on the other hand, you will find yourself having fun with all the side blows, hidden remarks and strange events you will be facing that it lets you discover. But be warned, half the fun is finding everything there is to find, and it certainly won't present all its beauty on a silver platter for the lazy CoD-Player to be consumed. And be to look up a *lot* of stuff on wikipedia when it comes to historical and/or political references. At least I had to, and the depth of several findings in there only revealed itself after getting to know the details of e.g. McCarthy era America or "Project Paperclip".Don't expect a lot in graphics, it is sufficient and functional, no more. But the attention to detail the Devs put into every single room, every single table, yes even every single rack standing around is just astounding, and makes the world more alive in your head than any stunning graphics dazzler puts in their levels.All in all, definitely not a game for everybody, but recommended nonetheless!

 I bought this, m8s. In a bundle. This is punk rock as sh*tDepending on your view this can either be a good or a bad thing. I don't understand why everyone feels the need to point out that the developers said it was like a B-movie, but I'm going to do the same thing. In fact, I'm going to go further and say that it's more of a C-Movie. If you're not into underground gore flicks, you're probably not going to enjoy this game. That genre translates well into this medium.Not B-horror, but C-horror and no budget horror. Look up a movie called Zombie Bloodbath by a Director named Todd Sheets - I think it's up on Youtube for free right now along with some other stuff. That's the genre we're talking about here. The worst recordings, the bottom-of-barrel editing. This game has it all, but tops it off with the worst voice acting I've ever heard. There are two ways to do horrible voice acting - good or bad. In this case, it's pretty good. I was asked to review the game...Not by the developer, but it came up from someone I know, and it had been awhile since I've picked it up and played it - so WHY NOT, I figured, I'll play it again. Sometimes the humor in it can be way, way too much to deal with - that's just the nature of low budget/no budget movies put into a game. The mini game doesn't work at all.Never has. The game is huge...5 gigabytes is ridiculous for something like this. If you want something a little different...If you want something a little different, you should look elsewhere. If you want something a lot different, you might like this. As other people have said, this game feels a lot like something you yourself could make. In fact, it seems like something you yourself could make with very little effort - even though a lot of effort probably went into it. It's made with Game Guru, which I still maintain doesn't make a game bad - and it's pretty goofy. There are some really bizarre hiccups in the game that should really be ironed out, but if you can deal with closing and reopening a game a bunch of times, they're not too bad. Warning: light spoilers (not touching the story) inside. Into the review: I’ll try to waste as much of your time as possible, so sit down and make yourself comfortable ;)Into the graphics: It’s hard to discuss the thing that does not exist (except God, of course), so we’re lucky there’s too dark to see the trashy and horrific textures or sprites.Into the sound: At first I understood nothing of the narrators mumbling and was about to quit, but suddenly came across this note from devs. After that I had been drinking for three days before the things were sorted out, at least I got the idea that the protagonist must be somehow (magic wand?) converted into a gay and placed into the Playboy mansion. Hmm.Into the violence: You know, I’m from former Soviet Union, so from time to time I had to cover my on-table dog’s head connected to artificial heart with a rag to protect it from seeing many outrageous scenes.Into the racist jokes: Can’t stand them. I hate two things in life – racism and some lower races.Into the scientific value: If you complete the game you will surely solve ‘Schrödinger's cat’s paradox'. Or not. Whatever.Into the monsters: They are really scary. Have a look at this one.  I fought it in the middle of the game, but for sure it would perfectly suit to any AAA horror project as a main boss!Into the achievements: On finding a vintage adult movie I unlocked the achievement “History of p0rn”. I could have recollected one of the first adult movies I had seen in my life – it was called “Look what’s up my @$$”. As for me – a great replacement for the original game title! Into the game itself: On my half-way through I understood that I was in Matrix. Unfair Matrix with agent Smith, but without any call-boxes to get out. Since that very moment I spent all my efforts looking for the way out. I even forgot I had been playing to see some promised boobs and was greatly surprised when suddenly came across them. By the way, boobs were pretty good! (I haven’t posted the screenshot; otherwise everyone will lose any motivation to beat this game;) But even after that my intention of escaping was strong. In a level called “Into the green” I finally managed to get over the fence and breathe the smell of freedom. Beautiful green textures with roses were my reward. As you can see all I had left was a business card of some Henry Von Edelkase, probably, he was a psychologist and I had to phone him in order to forget everything I had seen in game. Not sure, better call Saul.P.S. Really, I love this game very much, it has made me laugh not once during the walkthrough, and I greatly appreciate it. P.P.S. Special thanks for the song “Katusha” in German. P.P.P.S. ‘Marasmus + diligence = decent trash’ (c)
